title: Linda Lindsay
text:
Linda Rose Lindsay (; born 28 February 1950) is a New Zealand former <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er who played as a right-handed <a href="Batting%20%28cricket%29">batter</a> and right-arm <a href="Fast%20bowling">pace</a> <a href="Bowling%20%28cricket%29">bowler</a>. She appeared in two <a href="Women%27s%20One%20Day%20International">One Day Internationals</a> for <a href="New%20Zealand%20women%27s%20national%20cricket%20team">New Zealand</a> at the <a href="1978%20Women%27s%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">1978 Women's World Cup</a>. She played domestic cricket for <a href="Wellington%20Blaze">Wellingon</a>.
Lindsay was born in <a href="Wellington">Wellington</a>. Her younger sister, <a href="Cheryl%20Henshilwood">Cheryl Henshilwood</a>, also played international cricket. Lindsay made her debut for Wellington during the 1970–71 season. Her international debut came at the 1978 World Cup in India. Lindsay debuted in New Zealand's second match of the tournament, against <a href="India%20women%27s%20national%20cricket%20team">India</a>, and took 2/26 from ten overs as her team won by nine wickets. She played her second match in New Zealand's final game, against <a href="England%20women%27s%20cricket%20team">England</a>, and scored 27 runs from fifth in the batting order, behind only <a href="Barb%20Bevege">Barb Bevege</a> among her teammates. She was less successful with the ball, however, conceding 16 runs from three overs without taking a wicket. Lindsay finished her career for Wellington after the 1978–79 season.
